Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän - I apologize for the chaos. We weren't expecting you for another few hours.
Quite all right. Given the situation, I don't think standing on ceremony would've been appropriate anyway. You're...
Ah, 'tschuldigung. Oberleutnant zur See Walther Voss. Second watch officer.
It's not the second watch, is it?
As I say, apologies for the chaos. We'll get you squared away as soon as we can, but--
But right now I need to get to the bridge - agreed. Let's see if we can shoo away these Morganas before they get too close to Copenhagen.
"Shoo away?"

Fields.MenuText: I don't mean to sound conceited, Oberleutnant, but I have something of a history of eliminating destroyers.
Probably a poor choice of words.
Shoo away.

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr gut, Kapitän.
Um... have you met the Schiffsdame yet, Kapitän?
Briefly, but not in a really meaningful way. Anything I should know?
Hm. Don't be surprised if she uses the royal we if she's on the radio or speaking formally on behalf of the ship.
... Okay.
If she's in a bad mood, you can usually forestall trouble by complimenting her glasses or her clothes. Don't call anything she wears dated or out of fashion, especially if it is.

Fields.MenuText: Right. She's one of those Belles. Got it.
Maybe this should wait until after the shooting.
Noted. Thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: The bridge is right this way, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
And I think that's the end of the inspection tour.
It has been Our very great pleasure to escort you around your ship, Kapitän. We trust everything has been to your satisfaction.
I certainly have no qualms about the physical state of the ship. The crew, on the other hand-
We have a full complement, Kapitän, and their training is going well. The complications with the organizational framework were beyond Our control.
Both the government and the League were very... curious about what happened at the Westerplatte. At the start of the war. Many of the crew members who were there were sent home for questioning.
And there would have been losses, too. The Mist.
Ja.

Fields.MenuText: You have my condolences, for what they're worth.
That was a hard day for anyone at sea.
Well, it's our job to avenge them now.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke, Kapitän.
So it seems.
Ja. So it is.
You'll have heard we've received our orders. They're somewhat complicated, but important.
Important?
Complicated how?
Whatever the Morganas have been up to in the Gulf of Bothnia, they seem to be turning their attention south. Multiple sightings of capital ships as far south as Gotland.
It need hardly be said that if Stockholm is under threat from battleships and aircraft carriers, then the usual west Baltic patrols aren't enough to deal with the problem.
Ah, ja. The Reich needs its Swedish iron.
And the Soviets don't want the Baltic Fleet to have to fight to the death just to get out of Leningrad. And the League wants everyone else to be happy.
And the complication?
We go in fast, and we keep as far away from the Gulf of Danzig as we travel as is physically possible.
And what bregenklöterich sot of an admiral got that idea into the-
Careful! You don't want to fog those lovely glasses.
... Ja. Quite right.
They may seem unnecessary, but they *are* our orders, and I don't see any practical reason they should be challenged. Do you?
We... do not.
And We have other problems to consider now, regardless.
You're sensing Morganas?
Ja. From the Atlantic, I think. The British let too many fish through their nets.
I'll make sure to pass that along.
@BATTLE
It's good to see with human eyes what you've done with your quarters, Kapitän. Thank you for inviting me.
Should I ask how you perceive the room without human eyes? As a Belle, I mean?
Oh, I respect your privacy. I only peek if someone does something to make the floors itch.
I... hope that doesn't happen often.
You may be better off not knowing.
Probably. And I feel like I should thank you for setting aside the pluralis majestatis for our talk. The royal we can be kind of awkward in informal conversation.
With you, I think I can assume my majesty is mutually understood and in no need of emphasis. Also I've been dipping into the grog.

Fields.MenuText: Grounds for a solid working relationship, all around.
Not dipping too deep, I hope.
You and me both. It's been a long day.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you think so!
That sounds like a euphemism, and it intrigues me.
Wunderbar!
I'm afraid that wasn't my intent.
Ah, but would Doctor Freud agree?
Uh...
So. How close do you think we could get to Danzig without running afoul of the admirals?

Fields.MenuText: The southernmost parts of the Kalmar Strait.
Why do you ask?
Not as close as I gather you would like.

Fields.DialogueText: Droll, but unwelcome.
Tcht.
Would you think I was childish if I said that I just wanted to see that the people there were happy? With my own eyes?
*sigh*
Schleswig-Holstein, the place I'm named for... not so long ago it wasn't so different from Danzig. German-speaking majorities. A return to Prussia.
Call me sentimental, but it would do me good to see the relief in the eyes of the Danzigers. No matter what else is going on in the world.
... I'm not sure relief is the only thing you'd see.
Ja, ja. And orders are orders. Aber...
Nixe. Close. Verdammt.
Right. Better shake off that grog, Schiffsdame. I'll see you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Oberleutnant! Any idea where our Belle can be found?
Up in the rigging somewhere, Kapitän. She's figured out that this is as close as we're likely to get to Danzig, so she wants to get the best view she can.
From here. In mist.
Ja. Well, I don't even know why she would want to see that place. I don't know what the start of the war was like for you, Kapitän, but on this ship it was die Hölle. Hell.
The idea of going out of our way to be reminded of it is obscene. I almost think the League may just be taking pity on us by ordering us to sail on by.

Fields.MenuText: I'm afraid they're actually more worried we might summon more Morganas.
It's more that they're worried Polish elements in the Neutrality Fleet would see it as a provocation.
The League taking pity? Not Germany?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know that the Reich has a lot of time for pity, Kapitän.
Ah. I'm honestly surprised they care.
Mm. That's worth worrying about, for sure.
*ALARM*
Kapitän? Any chance this is a drill?
Afraid not, Walther. Sorry.
@BATTLE
We have had word with port authorities in Visby, Kapitän.
Really? We're still a long way out - I'm surprised we were able to get through the usual Morgana interference.
Ja? Perhaps Our signals are unusually powerful.
I certainly wouldn't rule it out.
Or perhaps there just aren't as many Morganas here as you've been told.
Is that what the Gotlanders said?
Nein. Or, rather, it's unclear. The mists have been relatively bad for the last week or so, and there have been reports of distant gunfire - Gotland itself has been quiet, but the people are afraid.
We suggested that We might pass by Visby in Our patrols, so that the people might see Us and be reassured.

Fields.MenuText: Not a bad idea.
I hope you really were that non-committal.
In future, I'd appreciate it if you would check with me before making that kind of offer.

Fields.DialogueText: We only said that We would discuss the matter with you, Kapitän. No promises were made.
Ja, nicht wahr?
Thank you.
How are you, by the way? I know you were disappointed by our course the other day, but I hope it wasn't too--
You needn't worry, Kapitän. We'll get another chance at Danzig.
I'm not sure our crew shares your enthusiasm, but--
Was? Of course they do!
I have the impression that some of them found your... last mission there to have been fairly traumatic.
You're mistaken! Worse, you've been misled! Kapitän, We were privileged that day to... to...
Verdammt.
Morganas?
Ja. Not any of our capital groups... I think... but still worth ending.
Agreed.
@BATTLE
You should get dressed, Kapitän - the delegation from Visby will be here soon. And you did promise.
Was? What is it?
This *is* my dress uniform. I'm wearing it.
What does that have to do with anything? We don't match.
Pardon?
Listen, everyone understands that the Neutrality Fleet's uniforms are cobbled together from whatever canvas and burlap one can buy in bulk when one reaches port.
There's no such thing as a dress uniform under those circumstances. You shouldn't even consider it. What you need to do is tailor your look to complement mine.
It gives the impression of unified authority, you see?

Fields.MenuText: Or you could dress more like me.
You want me to dress like a gorgeous but stern 19th century headmistress?
Unless those clothes are already made, I'm afraid this is the best I can do.

Fields.DialogueText: ... If you hadn't used the word "gorgeous" I think I would be quite unhappy with you right now.
Amüsanter Vorschlag, but let's stay serious.
A fair point, unfortunately. Perhaps you can just stand behind me.
... Kapitän, Nixe incoming. Diplomatic functions may have to wait.
Understood. Let me get out of this jacket and I'll meet you on the bridge.

I think this is not the dreaded collection of capital ships we were warned to expect, incidentally. These things are worth fighting, ja, but it might be that the normal west Baltic patrols can resume.
And *we* can go somewhere more vital to the war effort.
One thing at a time!
@BATTLE
Västervik should be somewhere over there, if you're interested.
I'm interested, but all I see is mist. They had to close the harbor, didn't they?
That's what the Visby set said. We still see no evidence that the enemy forces here are as strong as We were led to believe.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe.
A pleasant surprise? Haven't had many of those in this war.
I wouldn't let your guard down.

Fields.DialogueText: Natürlich nicht!
Pleasant? Wasting Our time isn't pleasant, Kapitän. It's almost a sin. Don't pretend you don't agree!
If We haven't seen real action by the time we get to Stockholm, perhaps new orders will be given.
Still...
Let's not get ahead of ourselves. We should get a better sense of what Sweden has been going through at Stockholm, and then-
*sigh*
Problem?
More gnats headed our way, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
*AAAOOOOOOOAAAAAAAAA*
Kapitän!
What the hell are we hearing, Oberleutnant? It's not the engines - is the hull buckling on us?
Nein. I don't think so, anyway. It's just... something that happens at night sometimes.
"Just something that happens at night sometimes?" That sound is going to carry for miles! If we ever need to be subtle, I don't want it giving away our position.
Plus, I can say from personal experience that it's really difficult to sleep through. We don't want the crew any more exhausted than they need to be.
Natürlich nicht, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: It's like we have a wounded moose in the ducts.
We're sure it's not the hull or the superstructure being deformed under pressure?
This is going to be some Belle thing, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: That seems unlikely, Kapitän.
Grin all you like. You haven't read all the Fleet reports I have.
Jawohl, Kapitän. As sure as we can be.
Our previous commanding officer worried that the enemy left some... strange ordnance somewhere on the ship in their early attacks, Kapitän. One of the devices that steals raw materials, perhaps.
I assume you couldn't find anything like that? More to the point, I assume the ship's Belle couldn't find anything like that?
Nein, Kapitän. And, I promise, we looked exhaustively. Everyone was awake anyway.
*AAAOOOOOOOAAAAAAAAA*
That's just... where's Schleswig-Holstein?
I'm sure she's sleeping, Kapitän.
Right. And her quarters are...?
We... don't know. Void space, cargo hold, maybe - she may even sleep in the ballast tank if she doesn't need to breathe.
Wonderful.
*ALARM*
Right. Let's table this for now, Walther.
@BATTLE
We fail to see what the problem is, Kapitän. We don't require quarters. We are in a constant procession around the ship, and We sleep where the mood takes Us.
Well, we - by which I mean *I* - need to know where to find you in an emergency.
Just shout. We can always hear you.
Could you please stop referring to yourself in the plural for just a second? It's distracting.
Jawohl, Kapitän. I'm trying to guide us into Danzig in fog that's so thick you can hardly--
Stockholm.
Ja. Of course Stockholm. Tut mir Leid - a slip of the tongue. I didn't sleep well last night.

Fields.MenuText: You and me both.
You might have done better if you'd had an actual bunk somewhere.
I'm sorry to hear that.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke.
Please trust that I have a system that works for me, Kapitän.
I'm sorry to hear it.
Look, I don't want to pressure you, but I am concerned. There's a good chance that noise we were hearing is in some way related to your well-being, and...
Nonsense, Kapitän. And, if I may, you might have more luck if you just admitted you wanted to be able to call on me after dark.

Fields.MenuText: Nice evasion.
I will neither confirm nor deny.
Let's keep it professional on the bridge.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, I promise you, I...
Damn. Morganas?
Ja.
Right. Let's get everyone to general quarters - time to earn our paychecks.
Am I supposed to get paid?
@BATTLE
Kapitän? Kapitän, forgive me for intruding. I just... I...
It's okay.

Fields.MenuText: This isn't the first time I've woken up to find a woman I didn't expect in my quarters.
What time is it?
Just take a breath.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I'm filing that away for future consideration.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't mean it the way it sounded.
Please don't.
Noted.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know. It's still dark outside.
Ja, Kapitän.
Now. What's happening? Are we under attack?
Ja. Ja, possibly in more ways than one.
Explain while I get dressed.

Fields.MenuText: And look somewhere else while I do.
And talk fast.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh*
Natürlich.
The sound you heard the other day... it was me. Not my hull, not my superstructure, me.
I have... nightmares. Sometimes. One was beginning tonight, but I woke before it got out of hand. And I've seen the reports - the Nixen, sometimes they attack in this way. Psychically, if you will.
And I begin to wonder if they might not be waging a secret campaign against me.
Are they close? Now?
We should be within firing range in half an hour.
And you didn't say anything about this sooner because...?
I had no idea it was even possible! We hadn't received classified League reports before your arrival!
Right. Okay, thank you for trusting me. Shooting battle first - but if you're under attack in other ways, I promise we'll find a way to fight back.
And... there's no need to tell the crew that I'm wailing like a siren, is there?
We'll say we suspect it's a Morgana psychological attack. It even has the virtue of being true.
Danke. Vielen Dank.
@BATTLE
Kapitän? What's the word from Stockholm?
I'm not done talking to people - I have a meeting or two lined up about unconventional Morgana warfare.
You have Our gratitude, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Thank me when I've found something we can use.
No thanks needed. It's for the good for the ship.
You're very welcome.

Fields.DialogueText: As for the port, it's... I guess "tense" is the word.
The mist was relatively light a few hours ago. We saw relatively little recent damage.
Agreed. They've been reporting big shapes in the fog, radio interference, unexplained sounds - no major incursions around the port itself.
So it's a feint. They want Us to believe their forces are concentrated here while they're busy elsewhere.
We've come under fire every day for days, though. I'd say the evidence is actually pretty strong that-
*raises eyebrow*
... Your uniform looks particularly lovely today.
Good eye.
Kapitän, We propose requesting a new assignment. Ja, the enemy is present here, but it seems that the capital ships are not - We would think a destroyer patrol could keep the area safe enough.
I think that's premature - and I'm *sure* that Command would say it's premature. The Stockholmers say they think the real threat is further north-
That's not what We were told.
I know. But it is what it is. We need to stick around for at least a few days to be able to file a decent report.
We... would like to dispute that point, but the enemy appears to be approaching.
But not capital ships!
Noted.
@BATTLE
I hope you don't mind the company, Kapitän. At least you were already awake this time.
So I was. And, no, I don't mind. More nightmares?
That's the first thing that leaps to your mind? Perhaps I just enjoy your company. You *are* very charming.

Fields.MenuText: Flattery will get you nowhere, Ship's Belle.
Flattery will get you nowhere, Ship's Belle. But don't stop.
I'd be more convinced if your hands weren't shaking.

Fields.DialogueText: That's fine. I'm already where I want to be.
Is that an order, darling?
Well, not if your heart's not in it.
Okay.
So what's going on?
... I almost always have nightmares, Kapitän. I always have, ever since I first woke up - as a Belle, I mean.
And the more I think about it, the more I think it might be because of the Morganas. I think most Belles don't have this problem, because why *would* we have nightmares? We're meant for war!
But I was... I mean, you know the circumstances under which I woke, ja?
You were the first ship to be attacked by the Morganas.
Ja. Ja, genau. It was just after the retaking of Danzig had just begun, and there they were! Firing at me from out of nowhere!
And who knows what they were capable of when they first arrived? Who knows what powers brought them here? Who knows what I could have been exposed to?
Whatever it was, I regret none of it, you understand. I'm proud to have been the first to face them and to survive.
But I want to be able to fight what's happening to me, if it *is* an attack. You understand?
... Why are you looking at me like that?
You just... hardly took a breath. You're usually much more measured in the way you speak.
Do you feel under attack now? Is the enemy close?
Ja. The enemy is always close. Surely you know that by now.
... Right. Then maybe we should go to the bridge.
Ja. Ja, that will make me feel better. Danke, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Kapitän? We are assembled. Would you do Us the honor of telling us why?
The news from Stockholm is... I don't know. At a minimum, it's bad. Morganas hit Gävle yesterday. Not the usual destroyer smash and grab - bombers. At least one carrier, maybe two.
Mein Gott!
The Swedes just don't have much AA support up there. There's word that the city is being evacuated, which leaves the enemy free to repurpose the port - or what's left of it.
We can't know without better intel, but I think there's a decent chance that their activity around Åland was a prelude for this - gathering forces.
And there are reports - verified reports - that some of the fleet that hit Gävle is moving down along the coast.
Toward Stockholm.
Toward Stockholm. Toward us.
Gut. That's convenient. We can meet them halfway.
Not yet. You told me yourself there were destroyers coming in from the southeast - I don't want to be lured away from a smaller strike if we're capable of dealing with it before the big one.
... The timing will be difficult. If We're slow in dealing with the destroyers, then We're in a pincer.

Fields.MenuText: So let's not let that happen.
I know. This feels more organized than usual. I don't like it.
Exciting, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän.
Be that as it may...
I know. It's what we've got.
Perhaps not the word We would have chosen.
You're smiling as you say it, though.
The destroyers first, then?
Yeah. Help our navigator with the course, and then don't be stingy with the fuel. Speed matters.
@BATTLE
Vanity group ahead, Kapitän! There may be more ships beyond them - We can't be sure.

Fields.MenuText: Assume the worst.
At least those destroyers aren't sneaking up behind us!
One thing at a time.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know how many of you here on the bridge have direct experience with a Morgana battleship.
I will say this - they want you intimidated. They want you panicked enough to give them openings.
Don't give them the satisfaction. They're big targets - hell, they're almost impossible to miss.
And they're fighting for nothing. They're fighting because they're hungry and stupid.
*We're* fighting to save Stockholm and to avenge Gävle. Once the shooting starts, they'll be more afraid of us than we are of them.
Now let's go win this thing.
@BATTLE
Right. Good work, everyone - let's get the fires out, and-
Kapitän! There's more!
What? Where?
I don't know! I - bombers! Incoming!
*BOOM*
We don't like running and We don't like hiding, Kapitän.
No. We don't.
But we're outgunned, we've barely recovered from that air strike, and - more to the point - we're not running aimlessly. We're luring the enemy away from Stockholm, and we're testing their stamina.
I have yet to encounter a Morgana group this big that can maintain integrity for more than a couple of days before turning on itself.
We should be able to outlast them until they start drifting apart if we can just keep ahead of the main group, fight off strays from the south, and actually use the fog to our advantage for a change.
Are you all right there, ship's Belle?
Ja. The plan is to run and hope they get bored. We understand.

Fields.MenuText: Save that frustration for the enemy, Schleswig-Holstein.
Let's have less hostility in front of the crew, Ship's Belle.
Good. Glad we're on the same page.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh*
Entschuldigung. We... did not intend to be difficult, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: I know.
If that's your definition of difficult, I'm looking forward to a long career with you.
Just don't let them get to you. That's half the fight right there.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, you should know that I'm picking up hints of Morgana activity to the east. Destroyers, I think.
... If they haven't noticed us, and they're not attacking civilian assets, let's give them the chance to move on. We're still too close to a dozen Vanities to make too much noise.
Verstanden, Kapitän.
That being said, if we can discreetly take out one or two stragglers, I won't object.
Understood.
@BATTLE
The fog is lifting, Kapitän. Does that change our plans?
It might. It definitely means we have to be more alert for bombers.
But I think it's time we start doubling back - if the armada did start breaking up, some will be going for Stockholm.
And we need to find a way to knock them out of Gävle, which is hard to do while tacking toward Latvia.
Ja, genau.
How are *you* doing? You haven't dropped by my quarters the last couple of nights - sleeping better?
No nightmares.
... Is that Schleswig-Holstein-speak for "I haven't slept at all?"
I think we're close enough now that you can call it "Sophie-speak."

Fields.MenuText: I'm a little bit flattered.
Thank you, but don't change the subject.

Fields.DialogueText: And if I known you were missing me at night-
But there's nothing to say on the subject, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Let's stay professional here.
Now there's a topic for another time.

Fields.DialogueText: Seriously, are you all right?
You're right, I haven't slept for a couple of days. I don't need as much sleep as humans do, and it seemed wise to be on watch against the massive Morgana fleet.
Natürlich!

Fields.MenuText: Stay focused, "Sophie."

Fields.DialogueText: ... Fair enough.
For what it's worth, I *have* been reviewing that League dossier we got in Stockholm. The one that purports to be about Morgana psychic warfare.
Does it... say anything useful?
Not really. In fact, a lot of it is just questionable summaries of reports *I've* written since the start of the war.
Wait. Kapitän. They've found us.
Which? How many? The carrier group?
One or more Vanities, I think. And hangers on.
Right. If it's just that, we should be okay. I'll meet you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
*gasp*
Sophie? Sophie, what's going on?
*GASP*
Es geht mir gut. Es geht mir gut. Everything's okay. I just...
How did I get here?

Fields.MenuText: You just appeared.
You mean that existentially or practically?
Don't worry about it right now.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha.
Ah. Ja. Okay. That's unfortunate.
Ja. Danke.
You tried to sleep and had a nightmare, I take it?
Ja.
Okay, I'm sorry to jump to the practical question, but: are Morganas close? Was this an attack?
I sense... I think there's something relatively close. Another Vanity group. But they're not on course to intercept us.
So this isn't an attack?
I don't know. It could be. You know what they're capable of! You know better than anyone!
Sophie...
Kapitän, if I'm just losing my mind, they'll make me a training ship again. I can't... that can't be allowed to happen.
Relax. If they're alone, let's just go deal with this Vanity group - that should clear your head.
Ja. Ja, gut.
@BATTLE
Is this a good time, Kapitän? I can come back later.

Fields.MenuText: This is fine. Have a seat.
Oh, come on. If we're not getting shot at, any time is a good time.
The thing is, that might mean showing up at two in the morning, semi-conscious, in the middle of a panic attack.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke.
You're too kind.
How are you doing?
I think you'll agree that my performance today was outstanding, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Agreed.
You're too tired even to be convincingly evasive, Sophie.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you think there's any chance the Morganas are going easy on us, Kapitän?
Pardon me?
I don't mean the human race or the world as a whole - or even Germany. I mean this ship. Me.
I've been thinking about it. They have this massive force in the area, ja? Why didn't they bring it against us when we first arrived?
Because they're not that organized, they share information erratically, and they've been doing other things. Sophie, if anything we've had it harder over the last week than I would have expected.
Why are you worrying about that in particular?
I was just... I was trying to think creatively, Kapitän. To put myself in their shoes and-
Yeah, I won't go so far as to say you're a bad liar overall, but you're not doing a good job lying about *this*.
They could have killed me before, Kapitän. At Danzig, when this all started. It was like they'd torn open the sky, and we didn't know what they were, and we weren't ready for them.
And I was barely awake, and my crew was dying from the mist, and I didn't see at first how to make it go away. I didn't have anyone like you with the presence of mind to give me orders.
They could have destroyed me. I don't know why they didn't. If it was some kind of plan - if they think I can be useful to them somehow, or...
Sophie, I promise you, they didn't have a plan. They were disorganized and they-
One of them, Malice, she said to me, "You could almost be one of us." They were the first words anyone ever said to me, as a woken Belle.

Fields.MenuText: That's not in your file.
That's Malice being Malice.
What do you think she meant?

Fields.DialogueText: Why would it be? No one else on my bridge was conscious to hear it.
Ich weiß es nicht! How should I know?
... Kapitän. They're close. Again.
Right. We'll come back to this later.
@BATTLE
Hello there, ship's Belle - do you have a few minutes? We should probably resume our last conversation.
We would, of course, be delighted, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: But?
We're doing the "royal we?" We're not on the bridge.
Excellent. I appreciate it.

Fields.DialogueText: You called Us "ship's Belle" instead of Sophie, Kapitän. That sets a mood.
But...
Sorry.
In any case...
We're approaching Stockholm - and so is another Vanity fleet.
Right. I'm not enthusiastic about that, but it strikes me as a good sign.
After they botched their last sneak attack, enemy air support is much reduced, and their armada really does seem to be splitting into Vanity groups.
I don't know what's waiting for us in Gävle, but with luck we can keep Stockholm from being overrun.
Ja? Let's see, shall we?
@BATTLE
Kapitän. I think you should know that We have been drinking. Moreover, We have discovered that it is very difficult for Us to become inebriated, and we are therefore in a foul mood.

Fields.MenuText: So you figured now was a good time to continue our discussion?
You might be a little bit more inebriated than you think.
Noted.

Fields.DialogueText: Stimmt haargenau, Kapitän. You are an officer of keen insight and... and perspicacity. Is that the word?
Nein, I'm trying not to think at all.
Sehr gut!
Sure, why not?
So, why are you trying to get drunk as we push into Morgana waters? Exactly?
They say it helps you sleep.
Sophie...
But, of course, I don't really want to sleep. Or, I do, but it's not right that I sleep and leave my crew to deal with this horrible, ridiculous war without me.
I started it, after all.
I fired the very first shots of the war, you know. The Poles weren't expecting it. As far as they were concerned, I was a guest.
Now, in my defense, I was a guest of Danzig. And the people of Danzig? German! Overwhelmingly German! It was a battle of reunification, not conquest!
Sophie...
... But I fired on Westerplatte, and like that - *SNAP* - the Morganas were there. And the whole world caught fire.
Kapitän, what if I committed a crime and the whole world is paying for it? How do you make amends for something like that?

Fields.MenuText: You weren't even awake at that point.
You do what we're doing - protect as many people as you can and look for chances to do more.
I don't know.

Fields.DialogueText: Morganas coming?
I'll deal with them swiftly.
... May I try to sleep on your floor? I don't want to be awake after all.
Sure. You can even have my bunk.
Danke, but no. Too soft. It's all yours.
Okay. But you're getting the blankets.
That's not...

Fields.MenuText: That's an order.
It's so if I get up in the dark and accidentally kick you I don't break my toes.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Ja, Kapitän. Thank you.
@BATTLE
Kapitän? Schleswig-Holstein wanted me to tell you that the carrier group is burning all its fuel to intercept us. They'll catch up before sunset unless we try to evade.
... We can't afford the delay.
Kapitän?
We've had contact with the Swedish authorities - they're still working on organizing their Home Guard, but they'll be throwing a good chunk of what they've got in the east at Gävle. Soon.
The Morganas will be shelling them from along the coast, and that's bad enough, but if we run and the carrier doubles back... I hear those bombers are pretty good at targeting tanks.
They're good at targeting battleships, too.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, but tanks don't have Belles.
I'm well aware.
Where's your sense of adventure, Voss?

Fields.DialogueText: I told my father I'd let that go the last time he got me out of jail.
... You'll have to tell me that story sometime.
Or maybe they do and just don't brag about it.
Let's assume not.
Well... ja, I suppose you would be.
Ja, ask me when the war's over.
So, where is our Belle right now?
I'm not sure. You can't just call her?
I'm sure if I ordered her to appear, she would. But... well, she wanted some space.
I'm telling you, compliment her glasses.
Noted.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, We are most pleased to see you - your timing is excellent.
I'm glad to hear it. Both parts.
Ja. We... regret that We have been so busy. We would not want to give the impression that you have fallen out of Our favor.

Fields.MenuText: It's okay. You didn't.
You're stuck with me either way, so...
Let's focus on the enemy here.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Ja, Kapitän.
Lucky for us both that We approve, then.
Sehr gut.
So what are we looking at? Are they coming out of Gävle to meet us?
Nein. They're coming up behind - they seem to have been lurking to the west of Gräsö as we passed from the east.
Probably not a battleship group, then?
Probably not.
Then let's get it over with as quickly as possible.
Ja, Kapitän.
And check in with me once the shooting stops, okay?
... Ja, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Kapitän? We should be in sight of Gävle by morning. If they don't send someone to slow us down first.
Which they will, I'm sure. Or, rather, somebody will come for us, never mind being sent - we're not being subtle, and they're back to being as disciplined as a pack of starving wolves.
Ja. Genau.
... No need to look so anxious, Sophie. I'm not going to bite.
We are not anxious. We are majestic in every particular, and majesty tolerates no uncertainty.

Fields.MenuText: Noted.
Can I talk to Sophie instead of the double-duchess? Please?
*laugh*

Fields.DialogueText: *tsk* Das ist einfach unhöflich.
You may.
Gut.
Kapitän... I don't apologize often, but I like to think I do it when it's appropriate, and it's appropriate with you.
When I came here the other night...
Mein Gott, this is awkward. Shall we just say I somehow found the perfect words and you accepted them and then we moved on?
Otherwise I'll bumble around indefinitely, and I think we both know that's not who I am.
Agreed. But, Sophie-
Bitte, don't try to make me feel better. Don't try to fix me. Everything's fine.
Is it?
Let's pretend.
Okay. Fair enough. But let me tell you about a feeling I have.
Is it the kind of feeling one sometimes gets when a beautiful woman is visiting one's cabin after dark?

Fields.MenuText: No.
No comment.
That too. But...

Fields.DialogueText: What I'm thinking about is more a feeling that, if you were there at the beginning of this nightmare, you'll have a place at the end, too.
And when that time comes, and when scores are finally settled, what you and I do right is going to matter more than anything we've done wrong.

Fields.MenuText: That's all.
Or else we'll both get killed and it won't be our problem anymore.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Danke, Kapitän.
That's... strangely reassuring, actually.
You want to try to get some sleep? You can even have the bunk this time.
Nein. Nein, it seems that fate has other plans.
The enemy?
Ja.
Damn. I'll meet you on the bridge.
Kapitän, before I go... thank you for helping me do what I need to do. Very sincerely.
*nods*
@BATTLE
When this is done, We will need new shoes.
Sophie. We're at Gävle. This will go into the history books as the Battle of Gävle. We should probably focus on winning it.
We do that by visualizing the world beyond the battle, Kapitän.
When the Morganas have been shattered and when the Swedish Home Guard has blasted their strange devices into screaming atoms, We shall have new shoes.
And so order is imposed upon chaos.

Fields.MenuText: Okay.
"Blasted into screaming atoms" is a pretty good line, actually.
Noted. Now focus on the enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr gut.
We *are* rather proud of it.
Natürlich, Kapitän.
Get ready, everyone. They're almost in range.
@BATTLE
Das ist lächerlich, Kapitän. Absurd! I don't need quarters on my own ship!
Your own quarters, your own bunk, your own private place. I'm not saying I think you were punishing yourself by sleeping in cobweb-filled void spaces-

Fields.MenuText: Gotta get more locks for that footlocker.
"Thank you for being my Belle." Good grief. I start falling for a woman and suddenly my conversational skills implode.

Fields.DialogueText: Nein! There are no cobwebs.
But as long as I'm your captain, you're going to be treating yourself with the respect you deserve.
And you'll need a place to put those shoes.
I had been planning to commandeer your footlocker.

Fields.MenuText: No.
That's something we'd have to negotiate.
Trust me, it wouldn't be safe. The stuff I keep in that thing...

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I would have made it worth your while.
Ah, Kapitän, you'll find I have so many gifts to trade!
You intrigue me, Kapitän.
Yes. Thank you. Moving on.
If you have nightmares, you can still always sleep on my floor.
It's technically my floor.
See? There you go.
... Thank you for being my Kapitän, Kapitän.
Thank *you* for being my Belle.
*nods*
Now. I need to start making arrangements for shoes. Kapitän, with your permission...?
Granted. And godspeed.
